pages.title: Project Setup
pages.description:
Getting a project setup is rarely easy. Luckily, we have a quick script that can do the work for us.

---

Running `> npm run setup` will do the following:

1. Install package dev dependencies
2. Create an output directory called "dist"
3. Install "concurrently" & "browser-sync" globally
4. Run our app in the browser

You'll find this "setup" script located in your *package.json*.


---

We'll be installing a lot of scripts from terminal. You may also want to consider installing the atom package ["platformio-ide-terminal"](https://github.com/platformio/platformio-atom-ide-terminal), which provides a terminal inside your editor.

tasks.description: Open a terminal in this project directory and run `npm run setup`. Save to continue.
hints: Open up Bash (terminal) in this project directory and run `npm run setup` to get setup
If you're using Windows, you may want to use Git Bash
If your setup fails, try running `sudo npm run setup`

pages.title: The Store
pages.description:
The "single source of truth".

```js
const store = createStore(reducer, initialState);
```

tasks.description: install Redux as a dependency.
import `createStore` from the redux module.
create your first store and call it `store`. Use a simple "reducer" function for now, let's say `state => state`.
hints: call store with a simple reducer, `const store = createStore(state => state)`

tasks.description: log your `store` to the console and have a look.
log `store.getState()` to the console
move the initial state to the top of the file, and pass it in as a second param your `createStore`
hints: Pass in `initialState` as a second param to `createStore`

pages.onPageComplete: As you can see, the store is just an object with various methods like "dispatch" and "getState". Let's see what these methods do in the next step.

pages.title: Actions
pages.description:
Events that change the data.

##### 1. Actions
```js
const action = { type: 'ACTION_NAME' };
```

##### 2. Action Creators

```js
const actionName = () => ({ type: 'ACTION_NAME' });
```

##### 3. Action Types

```js
const ACTION_NAME = 'ACTION_NAME'
```

tasks.description: create an action called `voteUp` and a type of 'VOTE_UP'
change `voteUp` into an action creator.
hints: wrap your output object in round brackets

tasks.description: add a param of `id` to your action creator, and a payload of "id"
create an action type for `voteUp`
Use the action type inside your `voteUp` action creator. Notice how your editor may autocomplete the action type.
hints: change "VOTE_UP" to use the constant VOTE_UP

pages.onPageComplete: Excellent! In the next unit we will look at how these actions can be used to transform data using a "reducer"

pages.title: Reducer

tasks.description: Extract the `state => state` function called by `createStore`, and declare it with a variable called "reducer".
Log the state inside of your reducer. What does it look like?
hints: Add a `console.log` statement inside of your reducer function

tasks.description: The reducer takes two params. The first is "state", call the second one "action"
Dispatch two voteUp actions through the reducer: `store.dispatch(voteUp(2))`. Change your log statement inside of your reducer to look like this: `console.log('state: ', state, 'action: ', action)`
Create a `switch` statement in your `reducer` and pass in `action.type`, the default return should return `state`
hints: Your switch statement should have a `default: return state`

tasks.description: The `switch` statement should have a `default` case that returns the state
add a switch case for `VOTE_UP`. For now, just console.log the `id` of the action passed in and return the default state again. Tip: destructuring: `const { id } = action.payload;`

pages.onPageComplete: There are a few "gotchas" that come up with reducers. Reducers must be "pure" functions, let's find out how to accomplish this in the next step

pages.title: Pure Functions

tasks.description: Time to make the VOTE_UP action change the state. Return a new list of Pokemon after incrementing "votes" of the pokemon with the matching "id"
hints: If the pokemon.id matches the payload.id, increase the votes by one
Don't forget to return the new state

tasks.description: Let's make a test to see that we are truly returning a new state. Call `Object.freeze()` on your `initialState`. `freeze` makes an object immutable - meaning the object can not be changed. And yet your reducer should still work, since it returns a new state each call.
What if we were dealing with multiple keys on the state. We'd have to ensure that our changes return a complete new state each time. Use `Object.assign`
hints: Try this: `case VOTE_UP: const pokemon = state.pokemon.map(...)`

pages.onPageComplete: Now that you have an idea of how reducers work. Next we can look at how to create multiple, modular reducers.

pages.title: Combine Reducers
pages.description:
Create modular, composable reducers with `combineReducers`.

Explanation here.

tasks.description: create a new `const reducers` and set it equal to "reducer". Pass "reducers" into your store for now, instead of "reducer". If this seems convoluted it is because we're trying not to break the app.
hints: Second, try this: `const store = createStore(reducers, initialState);`

tasks.description: We're going to create more than one reducer. They can't all be called "reducer", so rename your original reducer "pokemon". Make sure to set `reducers` equal to the new name as well.

When we use `combineReducers` we will be able to define the initial state inside of each reducer. To keep things working, we'll have to do this step by step. Copy the "pokemon" key from `initialState` and give it its own variable called "defaultPokemon". It should be an array with three pokemon.
Set your pokemon reducer first param, state, to equal "pokemon", and give it a default value of `defaultPokemon` using ES6 default params.
hints: Default params work like this: `fn(param1 = defaultParam, param2)`

tasks.description: Fix references to "state" inside your reducer to match the passed in value "pokemon"
hints: Change three references to "pokemon" in your pokemon reducer

tasks.description: Our initial state is now handled by `defaultPokemon`. Set the initial state inside of your `createStore` to simply be an empty object (`{}`).
import `combineReducers` from redux
`reducers` should now call `combineReducers` instead and call `pokemon`. `combineReducers` takes an object with keys of each reducer.

pages.onPageComplete: The state remains the same, but now our reducers are much more modular. In the next step, we will separate our code into it's own file
